Table 2 shows values of the plasma viral load
of patient 303, measured in RNA copies per mL,
begun. The corresponding scatter plot is shown in Figure 10.
The rather dramatic decline of the viral load that we see in Figure 10 reminds us of
the graphs of the exponential function
in Figures 3 and 4(a) for the case where the
is less than 1. So let’s model the function
a graphing calculator or computer to It the data in Table 2 with an exponential function
±n Figure 11 we graph this exponential function with the data points and see that the
model represents the viral load reasonably well for the Irst month of treatment.
We could use the graph in Figure 11 to estimate the
required for the viral load to be reduced to half its initial value (see Exercise 33). ±n the
next example we are given the half-life of a radioactive element and asked to Ind the
mass of a sample at any time.
Sr, is 25 years. This means that half of
Sr has a mass of 24 mg, Ind an expression for the mass
(b) Find the mass remaining after 40 years, correct to the nearest milligram.
(c) Use a graphing device to graph
and use the graph to estimate the time required
for the mass to be reduced to 5 mg.
D. Ho et al., “Rapid Turnover of Plasma Virions and CD4 Lymphocytes in H±V-1 ±nfection,”
